Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: Correctness Verification Tools for Extreme Scale Hybrid Concurrency

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
High Performance Computing is strategically important to national competitiveness. Advances in computational capabilities involve the use of unprecedented levels of parallelism: programming methods that involve billions of concurrent activities. Multiple styles of concurrency involving shared and distributed memory programming ("hybrid") are necessary. Unfortunately, such programs are very difficult to debug using existing methods. This project develops formal (mathematically based) verification tools that can debug hybrid concurrent programs with very high certainty of bug elimination, while consuming only modest computational resources for verification.

The project develops execution-based tools that eliminate search over semantically equivalent alternative schedules as well as solver-based techniques that eliminate classes of bugs over single runs. Scalable methods based on non-determinism classification and heuristic execution-space reduction are also being developed.

Expected results include: (1) development of tools based on formal algorithmic techniques that verify large-scale hybrid programs; (2) amalgamation of incisive bug-hunting methods developed at other research organizations within formally based tools developed in our group; (3) incorporation of our verification tools and techniques within popular tool-integration frameworks; (4) large-scale case studies handled using our tools; and (5) training of undergraduate and graduate students on these advanced verification methods, building the talent pool vital to continued progress in high performance computing with applications to science and engineering, energy/sustainability, and homeland security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:
This project was aimed at the basic requirement of creating debuggingsolutions in support of high performance computing. Submitted in 2011when the end of useful performance increase due to the doubling oftransistors ("Moore's Law") was clear to the community, this project'sfocus was in anticipating and addressing some of the debuggingchallenges in the offing due to the fact that programmers faced theprospect of programming using multiple concurrency models.
The use of multiple concurrency models is necessitated because of thescale and heterogeneity of applications, with portions of an HPCprogram having to run communicating messages (at a higher level of thecode hierarchy), with the lower levels of the code employing CPUthreads, and the lowest levels employ offloading solutions to GPUaccelerators. While these mechanisms are clear, the intellectualeffort needed to guarantee that such a program will compute correctlyand reliably is massive. Given the absence of a coherent logicalapproach to develop such codes, and even this notwithstanding, giventhe inability of the human mind to avoid program bugs, newer types ofdebuggers that find bugs in these hybrid concurrency paradigms areneeded.
Intellectual Merits:
This project successfully demonstrated debugging methods and tools forMPI message passing programs, OpenMP threaded programs, and GPUaccelerator programs. The project employed formal methods with apractical slant in such a way that the scientific techniques wouldapply to real-world codes and be usable by programmers. Details of thescientific principles employed in our tools are well documented in ourpublications.
Broader Impacts:
Our tools for verifying extreme-scale hybrid concurrent programs havebeen released and are having multiple tangible impacts. Some of thesetools have been taught at the Supercomputing conference series as partof advanced tutorials. Others have transitioned to nationallaboratories, and are already helping to debug production codes.  Theproject also has had the great fortune of training research staff andPhD students, and also involved undergraduates in these projects.
All in all, this SI2-SSE project "Correctness Verification Tools forExtreme Scale Hybrid Concurrency" has met its stated goals in terms ofintellectual merits and broader impact.
